projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p:
AGAINST
Sir Iohn Clotworthy.
Sir Wil. Waller.
Sir Philip Stapleton.
Sir Iohn Maynard.
Sir William Lewis.
Maj. Gen. MaÅ¿Å¿ie.
Col. Hollis EÅ¿q.
Mr. Glyn.
Mr. Nichols.
Mr. VValter Long.
Colonell Harlow.
Members of the HouÅ¿e of Commons.
Together with the gallant AnÅ¿wer of the Å¿aid Members, to their Impeachment.
LONDON, Printed for George Whiting. June 19. 1647.

div.head: Articles of Impeachment propoÅ¿ed by the Army, under command of His Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, againÅ¿t Eleven Members of the HouÅ¿e of Commons read in the Å¿aid HouÅ¿e, June 17 With their AnÅ¿wer to the Å¿aid Charge.
div.p:
FOR yours which I rec â€¢ ived, I thank you; and for the Armie, to Å¿atisfie you in what you deÅ¿ire to bee reÅ¿olved in, in thoÅ¿e two great points of Mona â€¢ chie & J â€¢
Å¿tice. I Å¿hall tell you my opinion of them. They take not Holland, but Gods Word for a Rule to walk by, & to looke â€¢ n Monarchie, Å¿hall we think our Neighbors the Hollanders more kind or leÅ¿Å¿e cunning then States are wont to be that thus by way of EmpreÅ¿Å¿e, they publiÅ¿h to the World the well-Å¿pring of their own proÅ¿peritie, and the grand root whereby all other States may both perpetuate and enlarge themÅ¿elves. I believe rather, that as PhiÅ¿itians make not nice to give a receipt which they thinke Å¿ome others know, and thoÅ¿e that do not cannot procure the ingredients Å¿o the
Hollander conceiving this Benedictum medicamentum, Å¿uch as Common-wealths cannot be ignorant of, and Kingdoms hardly make uÅ¿e of, have bin willing to boaÅ¿t this Motto, as the honour of Demacracies, and the reproach of Monarchies. The firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e have no being without it, Å¿ince by concord, I Å¿uppoÅ¿e is here underÅ¿tood, a unanimous conÅ¿ent of the parts to purÅ¿ue one and the Å¿ame end, that is the good of the whole; and what conÅ¿titutes a Weal-publike, but this? Whereas in Monarchies (I Å¿ay not what Å¿hould be, but what is) the two conÅ¿titutive parts thereof, the King and People, have Å¿till Å¿uch oppoÅ¿ite intereÅ¿ts, the one of more libertie, the other of more abÅ¿oluteneÅ¿Å¿e, that it is hard to aÅ¿Å¿igne an object proportionate to both their happineÅ¿Å¿e wherein to reconcile and concentricate their aimes. I erre to Å¿ay, it is hard to aÅ¿Å¿igne Å¿uch an object, Å¿ince the happineÅ¿Å¿e and flouriÅ¿hing of a Kingdome in generall, is confeÅ¿t by that wherein both Prince and Peoples felicitie conÅ¿iÅ¿ts; but the difficultie lies in engaging both parties, in Å¿uch zeale and ardence to promove that one and common end, as may overbear the more Å¿enÅ¿ible intreÅ¿ts of their own individuals that Å¿hall urge them contrarie wayes.
The difficultie of kindling on both Å¿ides this uniting and evertuating ardour proceeds principally from three cauÅ¿es, one peculiar to each, and a third common to both.
FirÅ¿t, that Princes Å¿eldome or never reflect upon the originals of their authority and preheminence.
Secondly, that the people think as rarely of the reaÅ¿ons of their Å¿ubjection.
And thirdly, that neither do rightly conÅ¿ider themÅ¿elves in their nobleÅ¿t condition of relation to the whole, but in the abÅ¿tractedneÅ¿Å¿e of their inferiour and perÅ¿onall beings.

For did Kings but remember how they became Å¿uch, by the peoples confidence in their vertue, and why that fee'd,
as it were by dignity and honour above all, they might make the tranquility and comfort of all their care; and did the people weigh the voluntarineÅ¿Å¿e of their own Å¿ubjection how their Votes were given for Monarchie in their predeceÅ¿Å¿ors aÅ¿Å¿ents, or the motives thereunto, their own greater quiet and Å¿ecurity, by conferring more cares then honours on their Å¿uperintendent. Or laÅ¿tly, did both but ponderate what a Å¿uperiour thing in nature to either of them, is that reÅ¿ult from them both which we call a Kingdome; and of what greater dignity even they are, as co â€¢ Å¿titu â€¢ ive parts of that whole, then as headleÅ¿Å¿e or bodileÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿tents of themÅ¿elves, it were unpoÅ¿Å¿ible but both Prince and people muÅ¿t flame into as Å¿trict an union of affections to advance that excellent end, as we Å¿ee all parts of nature it Å¿elfe combind in for the preÅ¿ervation and ornament of the univerÅ¿e. In God, Unity and E â€¢ ernity are convertible, in nature, the beÅ¿t imitation of his perfection, union, and duration, are unÅ¿eparable, and in States permanence without u â€¢ animity imp â€¢ Å¿Å¿ible.

And for JuÅ¿tice and RighteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, to Å¿atisfie you in that alÅ¿o as concerning the execution thereof, they defire the ex â€¢ end â€¢ o all perÅ¿ons, and in all caÅ¿es. But to give you accompt to that which you deÅ¿ire more particularly, in relation to charge againÅ¿t Members; it is thus.

For the Å¿etling and Å¿ecuring of the common right, freedome, and peace of the Kingdom, wherof the Army have a Å¿hare: they have received Å¿uch informations as have been brought to them concerning divers perÅ¿ons, Å¿ome of whom are perÅ¿ons of eminency: yet they have proceeded to a charge, which they have drawn up, and Å¿ent
to the houÅ¿e of Commons againÅ¿t 11 of their own Members.
I. The Army hath charged them in a generall way to appear.
1. To have a will, confidence, credit, and power to abuÅ¿e the Parliament.
2. To have the like will, confidence, credit, and power to abuÅ¿e the Army.
3. To be unjuÅ¿t and high in the proceedings againÅ¿t the Army.
II. The Army hath Å¿ent up a particular Impeachment againÅ¿t them, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of Å¿everall heads, As acting things tending to the Å¿ubverÅ¿ion of the Lawes and Rights of the Subject To Å¿tirre up perÅ¿ons againÅ¿t the Parliament. To hinder the buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e of Ireland, and other generall things Signed by John RuÅ¿hworth Secretary, by their appointment, expreÅ¿t in their papers Å¿ent to the houÅ¿e of Commons.
If theÅ¿e Gentlemen, upon tryal, Å¿hal appear innocent, then it will juÅ¿tly appear, that the Armies deÅ¿ignes are dangerous, and that bee cleare which now is made an obÅ¿truction.

As for the Lords, there are no Members of the houÅ¿e of Pieres charged by the Army, as yet, nor any Citizen of London But the Army have another PropoÅ¿ition concerning the houÅ¿es, and that
is to have them purged of Å¿uch Members as they Å¿hall make appear to be Delinquents, &c. Something alÅ¿o they have to bring, Deputy Lieutenants of Counties, Members of Country Committees (and others who have beene entruÅ¿ted with the States Money) to accompt: And the proteÅ¿t, the uttermoÅ¿t of their ends in all this to b â€¢ chiefly for Gods glory, and for juÅ¿tice and RighteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e. God grant a firme peace, and prevent further bloud-Å¿hed: Å¿o prayes,

closer.signed:
Your moÅ¿t humble Å¿erva â€¢â€¢
R. CORBET.

postscript.p: We wayt in great expectation of the City CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners.

div.p: Upon ThurÅ¿day laÅ¿t being the 17. of this inÅ¿tant June, the houÅ¿e of Commons took into conÅ¿ideration the Impeachment of their Members, and read their charge Å¿ent up from the Army: at reading whereof, the Members charged delivered in their AnÅ¿wers, which was to this effect,

That they deÅ¿ired their Charge might bee Å¿peedily put into a way of tryal, declaring their willingneÅ¿Å¿e to deny themÅ¿elves, and their own
priviledges, to give Å¿atisfaction to the whole Kingdome.

list.head: The Names of the Eleven Members of the HouÅ¿e of Commons, impeached by the ARMY.
